div.fw: ¶Her͗e beginneth þe ꝓprolog of þe man of lawes tale·
div.l: Saue al þis compani grete and smale
Thus haue I quite þe millers tale
Here endeth þe carpenters tale of þe Miller of Trumpingdoıı̄un
And next biginneth þe prolog of þe man of lawes tale 
Oure host sawe wel þᵗat þe briꝫt sōnn
The ark of his artificiaƚƚ day hath y rōnn
The fourth ꝑpartie and half an houre mor͗e
And þough he were not depe stert in lore
He wist it was þe xviij· day
Of Apriƚƚ þat messenger is to May
And sawe wel þat þe shadow of eu͗ery tre
Was as in length þe same quantite
That was þe body erecte þat causeth it
And þer͗erfore bi þe shadowe he toke his wit
Þat Phebus which that shone so bright
Of degrees was xlv come on hight
And for þat day as in latitude
It is x of þe clok he gan conclude
So sodanly he plukked his horse abouȝt̄e
Lordyngꝭes qduod he I warne you al þe route
The iiij ꝑpartie of þis day is gone
Now for þe loue of god and Seint Iohn̄
Leseth no tyme as ferforth as ye can or may
Þe lordingꝭes þe tyme wasteth night and day
And forloth vpon̄ vs what with sleping
And þorgh necligence in oure walking
As doeth þe streme þat torneth neủer a yane
Discending from þe mountaign̄e vnto þe playne
Wel can Senek and many a philosophre
Wale tyme moore þan gold in cofre
For losse of cateƚƚ mai wel recouered be
But losse of tyme shendeth vs qduod he
It wol not come a yene with outen drede
No mor̉e þan wiƚƚ Malkyns maidenhede
Whan she hath lost it in hir wantonesse
Late vs not tari þus in idelnesse
Sir man a lawe qduod he so haue ye blisse
Tel vs a tale a none as forward is
Ye ar̉e submitted þorgh your̉e fre assent
To stonde in þis caas at my Iugement
Aquite you now of your̉e be heste
Þan haue ye do your̉e deuer atte leste
Host qduod he deꝑpardeux I assent
